contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox film | name = The White Parade | image = Thewhiteparade1934.jpg | caption = | director = [[Irving Cummings]] | producer = [[Jesse L. Lasky]] | writer = [[Rian James]] (novel)/(screenplay)<br>Jesse L. Lasky<br>[[Sonya Levien]]<br>Ernest Pascal | starring = [[Loretta Young]]<br />[[John Boles (actor)|John Boles]] | music = Louis De Francesco | cinematography = [[Arthur C. Miller]] | editing = | distributor = [[Fox Film Corporation]] | released = November 16, 1934<br /><small>(United States)</small> | runtime = 80 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''The White Parade''''' is a 1934 film that was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]]. It was written by [[Rian James]], [[Jesse Lasky Jr.]], [[Sonya Levien]] and Ernest Pascal, from the novel by Rian James. The film was directed by [[Irving Cummings]]. Dedicated to "the memory of Florence Nightingale", the plot concerns the travails and romances of young women as they study to become nurses. It stars [[Loretta Young]] and [[John Boles (actor)|John Boles]]. The only surviving print is located at the UCLA film archive, and can be viewed at the Instructional Media Lab, Powell Library, after making an appointment. The print is in rough shape; several frames are out of alignment, at times, while the whole picture looks bleached out and very fuzzy. As well, near the end of the film, a sign pops up indicating "reel 7"; fast forward and you can see the rest of the film. This is one of two Best Picture nominees that have never been released on home video. The other is [[East Lynne (1931 film)|''East Lynne'' (1931 film)]]. ==Cast== *[[Loretta Young]] as June Arden *[[John Boles (actor)|John Boles]] as Ronald Hall III *[[Dorothy Wilson (actress)|Dorothy Wilson]] as Zita Scofield *[[Muriel Kirkland]] as Glenda Farley *[[Astrid Allwyn]] as Gertrude Mack *[[Frank Conroy (actor)|Frank Conroy]] as Dr. Thorne *[[Jane Darwell]] as Miss 'Sailor' Roberts *[[Sara Haden]] as Miss Harrington *[[Joyce Compton]] as Una Mellon *[[June Gittelson]] as Lou 'Pudgy' Stebbins *[[Polly Ann Young]] as Hannah Seymour *[[Noel Francis]] as Nurse Clare *[[Jane Barnes]] as Miss Watkins ==Reception== The film was a success at the box office.<ref>THE YEAR IN HOLLYWOOD: 1984 May Be Remembered as the Beginning of the Sweetness-and-Light Era By DOUGLAS W. CHURCHILL.HOLLYWOOD.. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 30 Dec 1934: X5. </ref> ==Awards== ''The White Parade'' was nominated for the Best Picture Oscar in 1934. [[Loretta Young]] also appeared in ''[[The House of Rothschild]]'' the same year, which was also nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]].<ref name="Oscars1935">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/7th-winners.html |title=The 7th Academy Awards (1935) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=2011-08-07|work=oscars.org}}</ref> The film was also nominated in the category [[Academy Award for Best Sound|Sound Recording]] ([[Edmund H. Hansen]]). ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{imdb title|id=0025986}} {{Irving Cummings}} {{DEFAULTSORT:White Parade, The}} [[Category:1934 films]] [[Category:Black-and-white films]] [[Category:Florence Nightingale]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Irving Cummings]] [[Category:1930s drama films]] [[Category:Medical-themed films]]
